text: >> This episode of the Modern Rogue
brought to you by the wrath of god!
[laughs]
>> Repent now!
For ye end is at hand!
>> Also Squarespace.

and get 10% off your first order.

>> Jason Murphy, I can
only think of one reason

we would have our hemo
master and our mixologist
here in the same place at the same time.

>> Bar fight!
[laughing]
>> All of a sudden two swords come out.
[laughing]

>> Every D&D game I've ever
played all comes down to this.
[laughing]
Roll for initiative!
[smooth music]
>> NARRATOR: Making three mead cocktails.
>> We are here at the Parker Jazz Club
with our resident bartender, Trevor.
As well as our mead guy, Anthony.
>> Mead guy!

>> JASON: We're going to
craft a mead cocktail.
>> It's called synergy people.
I'm glad we finally made this happen.

>> Yes and then we are going
to bring in Coach Mikal
in as well and he's going to choke out--
>> He's going to get really drunk.

>> One chokes and it's
going to get real ugly.
>> JASON: What'd you got?
>> Well, I got three different ones
and we can--
>> Oh! I didn't know we had three.
>> Yeah, and--
>> I didn't either.
>> This is a threefer. This is amazing.
>> Well, I've never done this.
So, I figured one of them will hit.

>> Yeah, all right!
[laughing]
>> That works.
>> Okay. What's the first one?

>> We're going to be making
a Mead Old Fashioned,
but it's going to be a smash variety.

>> Okay, but Old Fashioned
uses whiskey right?

Like mead's nowhere near
that alcohol content.
>> Here's what's great about mead:
you can use it as the base,
you can add it as a sweetener,
or it can just be a modifier.
So, I can use it in different variances,
I can use it in different amounts

and it's going to change
the complexity of the drink
based on how much you use.

>> Well let's rock man.
>> Yeah.
>> Okay, let's do it.
So, when we did our Old Fashioned,

obviously we started with
sugar for the sweetener.

That is what the mead is
going to be in this drink.
>> Which makes sense

because mead is pretty
much just honey in water.
>> Right.

We're not going to use a
whole lot in this drink.
I'm actually going to use a half ounce.
>> ANTHONY: So, yeah.
This is the mead I made with you guys
and after I racked it,

I let it sit in an oak
barrel for about a week.
Just a gallon barrel a little bit smaller

so it's going to get a lot
more of that oak flavor faster
than you would in a larger barrel.
>> Is that just to add a little robustness
to the flavor profile?

Cus otherwise, it seems
sugary sweet all the time,

but a little bit of oak
gives it some character.
>> Yeah.
It's more depth of character to it.
Sort of trying it.
Which we probably should try it
before we drink it mixed, right?
>> Eh, whatever.
>> At least sniff it.
>> We can try it.

>> Yeah, take a little
snort of that Brian.
>> Oh, wow!
I just did it again.
I did that thing that I do.
That all like, "Oh, that's interesting."
[laughing]

>> Oh! I'm so sorry we made
you self-conscious of that!
[laughing]
>> That is a surprisingly complex bouquet.
So, have you tried this yet?
>> Yes.
>> What do you think?
It is always a magic trick to me

cus I always feel like
it's going to be too sweet
and you're so right,

adding that oakiness in
there gives it that texture.
>> Balance that out, pull that down.

>> Which you talk about
aging it with the oak

that's really going to go
well with the rye whiskey

that I'm going to use
today in this smashed.

It's still kind of summer
because we are in Austin, Texas.

So I'm going to do kind
of a summer smash here

which is typically a blackberry
and orange muddled together.
When we did the Old Fashioned,

I always talked about how when
you're muddling your fruits
you're just trying to get the oils.

This, we're going to
smash the Hell out of it.

>> BRIAN: That's the thumbnail
is just Trevor smashing it.
>> JASON: That's the title!
>> ANTHONY: Yeah.
>> Trevor Smashing.

>> That used to mean
something different in my 20s.
And then, just like the Old Fashioned,
we're going to use two ounces again.
>> BRIAN: Holy cow!

Anthony, I'm surprised at what
a strong aftertaste there is.
Like, a good 30 or 40 seconds,

I'm getting waves of more
of that oaky texture.
>> Getting different notes of that.

>> BRIAN: Yeah.
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, it really lingers.
I like it.
>> BRIAN: Any particular whiskey?
>> Yeah.

Today we are using a
Rittenhouse which is a rye
and it's bottled and bonded
which is any time a whiskey
is bottled and bonded it is 100 proof.
>> Okay.
>> Or over.
It's just overproof whiskey.

Now, unlike the Old Fashioned,
I am going to shake this.

[ice clattering]
>> Why?
>> Just to try to get those fruit juices
really going in there.
[cup tapping on table]
>> What's this one called?
Any name for it?
>> I don't know.

I've been thinking about
calling it the Notebook
since it's made with mead.
>> I don't know.
Is that a thing?
>> Oh my god!
>> I haven't seen the Notebook.
>> It's not the movie it's--
>> It's mead notebooks.
>> Oh! Goddamn you! Goddamn you!
Jesus!
[laughing]
>> TREVER: All right.
>> JASON: It's one of those bad puns
that was just so potent.
>> This is amazingly simple.

It's just fruit smashed up
with whiskey and a little bit,
not even very much,

just a little bit of
mead as the sweetener.

All right now I don't
normally like sweet drinks so.

>> We're going to call
this one the Notebook.

>> Man oh man! That makes
the whiskey real smooth.

I did not expect to like
that as much as I did.
>> Oh. That is really nice.

>> Yeah?
>> Yeah.
>> Are you much of a whiskey drinker?
>> I am.
That's pretty incredible.
I just get to smell it.
[laughing]
>> That's pretty good.
>> JASON: Yeah, that's great.
The Notebook!

>> Next, I thought that
since you make mead,
I like to make shrubs,
I thought we'd combine the two
and make the best of both worlds.
>> All right.
>> Now, explain shrubs to us again!

You've done it before,
but maybe not on camera.
>> It dates back to even ancient Egypt.
What they did is they would take roots,

herbs, vegetables, fruit, and
macerate them with vinegar.
With the acidity that was in it,

it would keep on the shelf
for as long as possible.

>> This is the same reason
all the Founding Fathers
drank beer all day every day
is because water would get unsafe

and this is a way to
make it just nasty enough
that it was safe.
>> Yeah, exactly.
So, for now, when I make a shrub,
what I do is I take some fruit,

whatever flavor I'm going
for, maybe some spices,
and I will macerate that with sugar

and let it sit for three
days and let all the--
>> What does macerate mean?

>> Well macerate is when you're
just chopping up the fruit--
>> This is a family show.
[laughing]
Don't drink the [beep] shrub dude.
[laughing]
I'm telling you.
>> This time I went with plum and peach

with a little bit of
habanero and cinnamon.
I took the fruit, chopped it up,
and then I cover it in sugar.

Then, I let it sit in the
refrigerator, uncovered

for about two days and
when I take that out
what you see is all of the essential oils
from the fruit has risen

and that sugar has almost
become a simple syrup.
Then, I take it outside,

let it sit in the sun
for about 40 minutes.
Come back in and I've just all this tangy,
tart, and thick syrup.

I'll just filter everything
out through cheese cloth
and what you have left is, basically,

you could almost just
call it a simple syrup,
but what you do in the end is,
when you have the base of it,
you just add vinegar to it.

And I typically use an
apple cider vinegar.

>> Man! You are like the
Bob Ross of cocktails

because it's like you were
describing a beautiful thing
and then you take a giant brown smudge
and just wipe it down the painting
and I'm like, "What are you doing?"
And you're like, "That's a tree."
[laughing]

>> There's no mistakes,
just happy accidents.

>> Yeah, right?
>> Exactly.
>> And happy little shrubs.
>> And I'll tell you,
some of the best shrubs I've made,

I didn't know what the
Hell I was doing at first
and it just turned out beautiful.
>> Are shrubs making a comeback?

Because, for the longest time,
I hadn't even heard of that.
>> I hadn't heard of it 'till today!
Today's the first day I heard about it!
I thought we were talking about plants!
>> It's over 4000 years old.
>> You would'nt've heard of it.
[laughing]

>> You don't need to add too
much to make a great drink.

You can just typically use
the shrub and a base spirit.
Maybe add an Amaro to it,
but you really don't need much
cus it already has the sugar in it
so you don't really need to add sweetener.
So it makes the drink easier to make.
So, what I'm going to do is,

I'm going to use a
little bit of this mead,
mix it with this and a little bit of gin,
and we'll see what happens.
>> A little bit of gin?
>> Yeah.

ounce and a half of my shrub.

And then, I'm going to
use an ounce of his mead.

And then, today, I'm

if you guys know what Kettle One is--
>> Oh, sure.
>> This is the Dutch family.
They own Kettle.

This is some of the

It is so smooth, and one

It definitely feels like it.
It feels comforting to hold onto.
>> And here,

ounce and a half of gin,
of the Nolet's.

We're actually using it as a modifier

Cus once you get over an ounce

>> Okay.

>> Quick refresher on how
mead should be done. Right?
>> Yup, yup, yup.

>> So you take your honey,
add some water, aerate it,

whether you shake it
or stir it or whatever,

add some yeast, shake
it a little bit more,

seal it, and then, when
it's done fermenting,

a week maybe two, three
to be really generous,
you're supposed to rack it.

So you get all that gunk
that settles at the bottom,
all the dead yeast, off of it.

>> So racking it means putting
it up on the rack sideways
so everything settles down, or?
>> No.
It actually means you get a siphoner,
pour out and like--
>> All: Oh!
>> So literally doing anything.
>> Yeah. Doing something.
>> So what's the window?
>> Because we took a different attack.

There's no longer off gassing.
You're going to like it.
It's going to be, probably, bone dry.

I mean--

It's true.
